content: The Act titled "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" allows waiver of sovereign immunity under the 11th Amendment for enforcement of USERRA. The Act "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" allows waiver of State sovereign immunity under the 11th Amendment for enforcement of USERRA in actions against a State by employees. The "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" allows waiver of State sovereign immunity for enforcement of USERRA in actions against a State by employees, including provisions for rights and benefits authorized by the chapter. The amendments apply to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, before or after the enactment date, and to all actions or complaints filed under such chapter. UNENFORCEABILITY OF AGREEMENTS TO ARBITRATE DISPUTES ARISING UNDER USERRA. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code, prohibits the enforcement of arbitration agreements between employers and employees for disputes under this chapter, except in cases where parties agree to arbitration after a dispute arises or in the context of a valid collective bargaining agreement. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code prohibits enforcing arbitration agreements between employers and employees for disputes under this chapter, except in cases where parties agree to arbitration after a dispute arises or in the context of a valid collective bargaining agreement. The validity and enforcement of arbitration clauses shall be determined by Federal law, with courts deciding on the validity or enforceability of agreements to arbitrate, regardless of challenges made by the party resisting arbitration. This section applies to all contracts and agreements between an employer and an employee, regardless of the enactment date. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code prohibits enforcing arbitration agreements for disputes under this chapter, except in specific cases. The provisions apply to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred, and to all pending actions or complaints under chapter 43. Additionally, enhanced remedies for enforcing USERRA are addressed in the following section. Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include remedies for violations by State or private employers, allowing for compensation or damages in cases of violation. Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code now includes remedies for violations by State or private employers, allowing for compensation for damages incurred by affected individuals. This includes lost wages, benefits, or other compensation, interest on the amount owed, and additional liquidated damages. The court may award liquidated damages not exceeding 100 percent of the compensation or damages awarded in good faith if the employer proves reasonable grounds for believing the violation was unintentional. In any action, the court can require the employer to comply with the provisions of this chapter. In cases of violations by employers with 25 or more employees, punitive damages may be required if the violation was done with malice or reckless indifference. A person initiating an action under this section is entitled to a trial by jury. Federal government employers are also subject to amendments regarding determinations by the Board. The Board can order a Federal agency to comply with employment provisions and compensate a person for any denied wages or actual monetary losses due to violations. Interest on the compensation amount will also be included. The Board may award liquidated damages in addition to compensation for denied wages or losses, calculated with interest. Liquidated damages can be up to 100% of the compensation awarded, unless the agency proves good faith and reasonable grounds for the violation. The amendments apply to any violation of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, before or after the enactment of the Act, and to all actions filed under chapter 43 after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5 amends sections 4323(h)(2) and 4324(c)(4) of title 38, United States Code, to require the award of attorney fees in actions to enforce USERRA provisions. The amendments apply to violations of chapter 43 before or after the Act's enactment and to all actions filed under chapter 43 after the Act's enactment. SEC. 6 clarifies the definition of "successor in interest." The term 'successor in interest' is defined for purposes of subparagraph (A)(iv) on a case-by-case basis using a multifactor test that considers factors such as continuity of business operations, workforce, job similarity, and equipment. The amendment addresses the successor's lack of notice regarding potential claims during a merger or acquisition. It applies to violations of chapter 43 of title 38, before or after the enactment date, and to pending actions or complaints under the same chapter. SEC. 7 clarifies that USERRA has no statute of limitations, applying to all violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred. SEC. 8 prohibits wage discrimination against members of the armed forces. SEC. 9 requires equitable relief when appropriate for violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, including wage discrimination against members of the armed forces. The amendment in subsection (a) applies to all actions or complaints filed under chapter 43, regardless of when they occurred. Section 4323(e) of title 38, United States Code is amended to require the court to use injunctions or restraining orders in cases where appropriate. An employer's denial of reemployment or retention in employment is considered irreparable harm, and the person affected shall be deemed to have no adequate remedy at law. The amendments made by subsection (a) require the court to use injunctions or restraining orders in cases of denial of reemployment or retention in employment. There is a rebuttable presumption that the harm to the person denied reemployment outweighs the harm to the employer if an injunction is not issued, and that reinstating the person is in the public interest and advances public policy. These amendments apply to violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code. These amendments apply to violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, occurring before, on, or after the enactment of this Act, and to actions or complaints pending on or after the enactment date.
